citeinfo.title: Water Districts: Santa Clara County, California, 2015
citeinfo.othercit: Retrieved on Friday, August 14, 2015 from the County of Santa Clara Planning Office open data portal at http://opendata.arcgis.com/datasets?q=santa+clara+county&sort_by=relevance. As of August 14, 2015, only partial metadata was available.

citeinfo.title: Santa Clara County, California GIS Maps and Data

descript.abstract: This polygon shapefile depicts water districts in the County of Santa Clara, California. A water district qualifies as a special district and is tasked with supplying water and sewer needs to a community. According to the 2009 Santa Clara Valley Water District Act, the purpose of these water districts is to provide comprehensive water management for all beneficial uses and protection from flooding within the County of Santa Clara. This layer is maintained by the Planning Office for the benefit of the Local Agency Formation Commission (LAFCO) of Santa Clara County. LAFCO was created in 1963 to encourage orderly formation of local government agencies, preserve agricultural land resources and discourage urban sprawl. LAFCos are responsible for coordinating logical and timely changes in local governmental boundaries, conducting special studies that review ways to reorganize, simplify, and streamline governmental structure and preparing a sphere of influence for each city and special district within each county. This layer is part of a collection of GIS data for Santa Clara County, California.
descript.purpose: The Santa Clara County Planning Office is part of the Department of Planning and Development. Their primary function is to plan and regulate land use and development within the unincorporated portions of Santa Clara County. Other responsibilities include policy analysis, GIS services, research and technical assistance relating to land use, housing, environmental protection, historic preservation and demographics. The Geographic Information Services Department has taken on all those activities related to GIS data and GIS process and procedures that cross organizational boundaries. Santa Clara County encompasses 15 cities and approximately 1.7 million people. This coverage can be used for basic applications such as viewing, querying, and map output production, or to provide a basemap to support graphical overlays and analyses of geospatial data.

idinfo.useconst: There are no Use Constraints. The user must be familiar with GIS software and web maps to use these data. No support on the use of software or webmaps is provided.
